declarations.comments:
The `RoutePropsClass` type class let one extend the properties passed to
each `RouteClass` react class component.  There is one instance
`RouteProps` defined in the `React.Router.Type` module.
The `mkProps` member function receives the name of the route and an
nonempty array of args read from the url.  You can use
`React.Router.Utils.last` function to get the last element of the array
with arguments obtained from the corrsponding url part.
declarations.title: RoutePropsClass

declarations.comments:
`ReactSpec` for the `link` element; it takes a record of type `LinkProps`
as properties.  The `props` record property is directly passed to underlying
`a` element, e.g. this can be used to add css classes.
declarations.title: linkSpec

declarations.comments: as `link`, but with empty properties passed to the underlying `a` element.
declarations.title: link'

declarations.comments: `link` element; use it instead of `a` to route the user through application.
declarations.title: link

declarations.comments:
React class for the `browerRouter` element.  Use it to init your application.
```purescript
 router = ... :: Router _
 main = void $ elm >>= render (createElement browserRouterClass {router, notFound: Nothing} [])
   where
     elm = do
       elm_ <- window >>= document >>= getElementById (ElementId "app") <<< documentToNonElementParentNode <<< htmlDocumentToDocument
       pure $ unsafePartial fromJust (toMaybe elm_) 
 ```
declarations.title: browserRouterClass

declarations.comments:
`ReactSpec` for the `browserRouterClass` - the main entry point react
class for the router.
declarations.title: browserRouter

declarations.comments:
Main entry point for running `Router`, it returns `ReactElement` that can
be injected into React vDOM.
declarations.title: runRouter

declarations.comments:
Router
```
router =
    Route "home" "/" Home :+
        [ Route "user" "user/:id" User :+
            [ Route "email" "email" UserEmail :+ []
            , Route "password" "password" UserPassword :+ []
            ]
        , Tuple (Route "books" "books" Books) (Just BooksIndex) :<
            [ Route "book" ":id" Book :+ []
            , Route "reader" "reader" BookReader :+ []
            ]
        ]
```
declarations.title: Router

declarations.comments:
`RouteProps` type keeps track route related data: id, currently matched
argument and array of arguments - if the route is nested this will hold
list of all parent arguments.
declarations.title: RouteProps

declarations.comments:
React component which will be mounted at matching node
It recieves array of all matching routes.
declarations.title: RouteClass

declarations.comments:
Route type
The first parameter is an identifier.
declarations.title: Route

declarations.comments:
IndexRoute type
The first parameter is the id property.
declarations.title: IndexRoute

declarations.comments: `:+` lets define routes without index route

    Route "home" "/" Home :+

Print `Routing.Types.Route` as a string,  useful for debugging.
declarations.title: routeToString
